html:
Names, umlauts, and the UX of respect.

“Cultural sensitivity is a mark of overall competence.” I don’t remember where I first heard this, but I wrote it down and carried it with me. As a human experience designer, I often return to this idea, especially as we enter this AI-driven era.

We’re automating fast, building systems that interpret, sort, translate, and generate on behalf of humans. As we teach machines to understand us, we need to ask — which us? Whose language, whose spelling, whose naming conventions, whose norms?

Meet Noël

Years ago, I made a client cry — not because something went wrong, but because I got something right. Her name is Noël. She told me I was the first designer to figure out how to get the umlaut (it’s actually a diaeresis to your typography nerds) to appear properly on her business card. Others had told her no, it’s impossible.

This seemingly minor typographic detail¹ underscores how design elements can profoundly affect user emotions and perceptions.

This was in my early days of graphic design while using QuarkXPress, the grandmother of InDesign. I probably had to load up the user guide CD and figure out how to make diacritical marks…
